definition: Having or showing a great desire to possess something belonging to someone else
passage: Criminal gangs operating in border areas can overwhelm civilian police, and in the future Brazil hopes to deter foreigners covetous of its natural resources.

definition: Traveling from place to place, in particular working or based in various places for relatively short periods
passage: A prodigiously talented—and peripatetic—chef, Mr Chang bounced around eateries in the south-east. One day diners at a strip-mall restaurant in suburban Richmond or Atlanta might be eating standard egg rolls and orange chicken...
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The apotheosis of Chinese cuisine in America", published in the Books and arts section of The Economist's print edition on December 21, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The apotheosis of Chinese cuisine in America

definition: Full of danger or risk
passage: In 2021 Brazil's president, Jair Bolsonaro, will have to navigate a perilous path to save the economy without sacrificing his popularity. The coronavirus pandemic cemented his reputation as an international pariah.

sourceTitle: Neither plagues nor scandals will topple Brazil’s populist president

definition: Offensive display of superiority or self-importance; overbearing pride
passage: Since the turn of the century they have shrugged off a dotcom crash, a financial crisis, terrorist attacks and political populism caused partly by resentment at their prosperity and arrogance.

sourceTitle: Great cities after the pandemic

definition: Extremely poor; poverty-stricken

sourceTitle: African governments are trying to collect more tax

definition: A person who disparages someone or something

caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Resting in glory", published in The Economist's "Eastern approaches" blog on December 24, 2011. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Resting in glory

definition: Be lying, situated, or kept in a particular place

caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The vandalism of modern warfare", published in the Books and arts section of The Economist's print edition on July 18, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The vandalism of modern warfare

definition: Made in exact imitation of something valuable or important with the intention to deceive or defraud

definition: Intense and passionate feeling

sourceTitle: Trade and immigration have never been so popular in America

definition: A noticeably rapid, strong, or irregular heartbeat due to agitation, exertion, or illness

sourceTitle: How will humans, by nature social animals, fare when isolated?

definition: Admit as acceptable or possible

sourceTitle: The family unit has shaped people’s experience of covid-19

definition: Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed

definition: A confusing and difficult problem or question

sourceTitle: A tantalising book of puzzles is a gateway to linguistics

definition: Feelings of anxiety or dismay, typically at something unexpected

sourceTitle: With oil prices depressed, China presides over a buyer’s market

definition: Pompous or pretentious speech or writing

sourceTitle: The "Wolf Hall" effect

definition: Disturb the composure of
passage: Unless they are stepping into an empty lift, people having a conversation should pause it for the duration of their ride, so as not to exclude others. Eye contact is best avoided... And even failing to face forwards can disconcert other riders.

sourceTitle: Covid-19 is changing lift etiquette

definition: Relating to or characteristic of an elegy

sourceTitle: The secret—and surprising—world of rare books

definition: The shameful failure to fulfill one's obligations
passage: It is a dereliction of duty that Latin America’s leaders have failed to come up with a joint position on many of the region’s pressing issues, starting with how to get international support to rebuild their economies.

sourceTitle: Spain’s complicated relationship with Latin America

definition: Place or lay (one thing) over another, typically so that both are still evident

sourceTitle: Admen have a clever new way to trick sports fans

definition: Something that counteracts or neutralizes an unpleasant feeling or situation

sourceTitle: Competence matters, and Johnson hasn’t got it

definition: Based on a mistaken belief
passage: Privately, the government believes that covid-19 has reduced the political risk of leaving without a deal, since its costs will be hidden by the greater damage from the pandemic. Yet this argument is not only improperly self-serving but also fallacious.

sourceTitle: Boris Johnson’s government should prolong the Brexit transition

definition: Threats, violence, constraints, or other action brought to bear on someone to do something against their will or better judgment

sourceTitle: China is growing more willing to review dodgy convictions

definition: (of a factor or situation) serving to lessen the seriousness of an offense

definition: Pass the final school-leaving examination

sourceTitle: Still dysfunctional

definition: A feeling of guilt or moral scruple that prevents or follows the doing of something bad

sourceTitle: Narendra Modi stokes divisions in the world’s biggest democracy

definition: Loyalty or commitment of a subordinate to a superior or of an individual to a group or cause

definition: Agreement or harmony between people or groups

sourceTitle: In Spain’s election, the Socialists win the most seats

definition: An amount paid to an employee upon dismissal or discharge from employment

sourceTitle: Corporate headhunters are more powerful than ever

definition: Likely or liable to be influenced or harmed by a particular thing

sourceTitle: Airlines have a chance to emerge from the crisis leaner and greener

definition: A twisting force that tends to cause rotation

definition: Scatter among or between other things; place here and there

definition: Not aware of or not concerned about what is happening around one

definition: Deep insight; great depth of knowledge or thought

sourceTitle: Grassroots leaders provide the best hope to a troubled world

definition: Blasphemous or obscene language

definition: Noticeable or prominent in an unwelcome or intrusive way

sourceTitle: What if technology tracked all carbon emissions?

definition: Decisively end or reject (something)

definition: Deceitful

sourceTitle: Might the pandemic be a lifeline for the rich world’s homeless?

definition: The action of officially absolving someone from blame

sourceTitle: China is growing more willing to review dodgy convictions

definition: Publicly denounce

definition: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people rather than by using rational argument

definition: A tendency to choose or do something regularly; an inclination or predisposition toward a particular thing

sourceTitle: What if technology tracked all carbon emissions?

definition: Beyond what is normal or natural

definition: Easily influenced or directed

definition: Deeply upset and agitated

definition: The quality of being well meaning

definition: Annoyingly insensitive or slow to understand

passage: If you’re contemplating a decision with long-term consequences, force yourself to concoct three different scenarios about how it turns out.

sourceTitle: Society doesn't think ahead but we can trick ourselves into doing better

definition: A person making a humble or earnest plea to someone in power or authority
passage: When he became prime minister, Boris Johnson insisted that he would not be a supplicant visiting continental capitals to plead over the terms of Brexit.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Boris Johnson’s German and French dealings", published in the Britain section of The Economist's print edition on August 22, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Boris Johnson’s German and French dealings

definition: A medicinal substance taken to give a feeling of vigor or well-being
passage: Long before we talked of'“superfoods' we consumed tonics, home remedies and pick-me-ups.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "What’s so super about super foods?", published in The Economist's 1843 magazine on November 1, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: What’s so super about super foods?

definition: Make (a problem, injury, or offense) worse or more serious
passage: Yet many rural Chinese think that wearing glasses aggravates myopia. In fact, squinting without glasses puts more strain on the eyes, and may cause sight to worsen.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Most 12- to 14- year-olds in China are short-sighted", published in the China section of The Economist's print edition on January 18, 2020. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Most 12- to 14- year-olds in China are short-sighted

definition: Present or organize in a different form or style
passage: But as data processing pervades more and more of human life, displacing and recasting all sorts of processes, experiences and relationships, is it really inconceivable that they might begin to impinge on the processes of choice central both to market economies and liberal democracy?
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Can technology plan economies and destroy democracy?", published in the Christmas Specials section of The Economist's print edition on December 18, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Can technology plan economies and destroy democracy?

definition: (especially of a person's manner or actions) insisting on immediate attention or obedience, especially in a brusquely imperious way
passage: Turkey’s president put the progress in jeopardy by sacking Murat Cetinkaya, the boss of the central bank. Though Mr Cetinkaya was not widely admired by investors, his peremptory removal unsettled markets.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Recep Tayyip Erdogan sacks the head of Turkey’s central bank", published in the Finance and economics section of The Economist's print edition on July 11, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Recep Tayyip Erdogan sacks the head of Turkey’s central bank

definition: Take apart (a piece of machinery or equipment) in order to examine it and repair it if necessary
passage: And although Mr Thiam overhauled the bank from top to bottom, he tended to promote from within (Mr Bouée was an exception).
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Tidjane Thiam is forced out of Credit Suisse after a spying fiasco", published in the Finance and economics section of The Economist's print edition on February 7, 2020. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Tidjane Thiam is forced out of Credit Suisse after a spying fiasco

definition: Clients collectively
passage: These customers are less wealthy than its usual well-heeled clientele, indicating that it too is expanding its customer base.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "What kind of bank will Wells Fargo be?", published in the Finance and economics section of The Economist's print edition on October 26, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: What kind of bank will Wells Fargo be?

definition: Laugh in a breathy, gleeful way; chuckle
passage: From Indianapolis to Innsbruck, they share the same open-source politics, fume over the same grievances and chortle over the same in-jokes.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Meet the IB, Europe’s version of America’s alt-right", published in the Europe section of The Economist's print edition on November 12, 2016. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Meet the IB, Europe’s version of America’s alt-right

definition: Unconventional and slightly disreputable, especially in an attractive manner
passage: He had a surprisingly raffish side. At Oxford he socialised with anarchists and punk rockers, rather than the Bullingdon set.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Whitehall’s mover and shaker", published in the Britain section of The Economist's print edition on November 8, 2018. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Whitehall’s mover and shaker

definition: The avoidance of excess or extremes, especially in one's behavior or political opinions
passage: Millennials, now in their 20s and 30s, are also drinking less alcohol. For them, moderation is part of a healthier lifestyle...
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Drinking is going out of style", published in The Economist's "The World in" blog on December 31, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Drinking is going out of style

definition: A spoken curse
passage: An English law of 1606 forbade profane references on stage to God, Jesus Christ and the Holy Ghost. Today such imprecations cause barely a batted eyelash...
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The polarisation of politics has led to a new lexicon of insults", published in the Books and arts section of The Economist's print edition on October 3, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The polarisation of politics has led to a new lexicon of insults

definition: The practice of exchanging things with others for mutual benefit, especially privileges granted by one country or organization to another
passage: Trade negotiators take a broader view of reciprocity. Yes, countries must give and take. But what is given and taken is political gain and pain.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Donald Trump insists on trade reciprocity. But what kind?", published in the Finance and economics section of The Economist's print edition on July 12, 2018. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Donald Trump insists on trade reciprocity. But what kind?

definition: Feel willing or favorably disposed toward (an action, belief, or attitude)
passage: Is university education itself behind these left-wing political views? Or are individuals with liberal values more inclined to attend university in the first place?
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Are left-wing American professors indoctrinating their students?", published in The Economist's "Graphic Detail" blog on January 9, 2020. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Are left-wing American professors indoctrinating their students?

definition: Change direction suddenly
passage: So it is best to cut losses quickly. If a forecast is right and prices veer in a new direction, they often travel a long way.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Why simple rules are best when spreading your investment bets", published in the Finance and economics section of The Economist's print edition on July 26, 2018. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Why simple rules are best when spreading your investment bets

definition: Cause to be under water
passage: There is little doubt that climate change threatens Panama. Rising seas will submerge the low-lying Caribbean islands of San Blas...
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Climate change threatens the Panama Canal", published in the Americas section of The Economist's print edition on September 21, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Climate change threatens the Panama Canal

definition: (of a subject or knowledge) little known; abstruse
passage: Talk of theory and whether someone is named in a document might sound recondite. But this has huge implications...
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Xi Jinping’s thinking is ranked alongside Mao’s", published in the China section of The Economist's print edition on October 24, 2017. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Xi Jinping’s thinking is ranked alongside Mao’s

definition: (of a natural force) sweep over (something) so as to surround or cover it completely
passage: The smallest country in the European Union (EU) is now engulfed in the biggest crisis in its independent history.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The prime minister and the murdered journalist: inside Malta, a nation on the brink", published in The Economist's 1843 magazine on December 13, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The prime minister and the murdered journalist: inside Malta, a nation on the brink

definition: Recover from illness or exertion
passage: Employees may work hard, but they will be allowed sufficient time to recuperate, and enjoy time with their families. In short, staff will be treated as people, not as mere accounting units.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Employee happiness and business success are linked", published in the Business section of The Economist's print edition on August 1, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Employee happiness and business success are linked

definition: Include or absorb (something) in something else
passage: The surprising survival of monarchies is in part a tribute to the nous of the old guard, who have understood the need to subsume their interests into those of the institution.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "How monarchies survive modernity", published in the International section of The Economist's print edition on April 27, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: How monarchies survive modernity

definition: Walk slowly and with heavy steps, typically because of exhaustion or harsh conditions
passage: I had so far trudged through seven miles of waterlogged fields, edging slowly past cows and taking detours to avoid getting stuck in the mud.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Walking the wall: my Brexit hike in northern England", published in The Economist's 1843 magazine on December 4, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Walking the wall: my Brexit hike in northern England

definition: Showing great courage in the face of danger, especially in battle
passage: Maya Lin's Vietnam War Memorial excels for many of the reasons it was initially controversial. From a distance, the long black slab looks more like a monumental tombstone than a celebration of valorous sacrifice.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "A blockheaded memorial", published in The Economist's American politics blog on August 30, 2011. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: A blockheaded memorial

definition: Overcome, quieten, or bring under control (a feeling or person)
passage: They point to Tibet, a neighbouring region with its own history of protest, where a resentful local population has been subdued without mass incarceration (though plenty of malcontents remain locked up).
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "In Xinjiang, China applies repressive lessons learned in Tibet", published in the China section of The Economist's print edition on December 12, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: In Xinjiang, China applies repressive lessons learned in Tibet

definition: Describe or regard as worthy of disgrace or great disapproval
passage: 'Before decriminalization, addicts were afraid to seek treatment...' says Manuel Cardoso. 'Now they know they will be treated as patients with a problem and not stigmatized as criminals.'
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Treating, not punishing", published in the Europe section of The Economist's print edition on August 27, 2009. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Treating, not punishing

definition: Evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret
passage: Her book contains a poignant description of her blighted childhood, dominated by his slow descent into addiction and ill health, and of her new life in Pittsburgh.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Running with Samantha Power", published in the October/November 2019 issue of The Economist's 1843 magazine. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Running with Samantha Power

definition: Poor; needy
passage: The anti-poverty programme it created, which involves giving assets and training to indigent women, has been copied by other charities and has been shown to work in countries as diverse as Ethiopia, Honduras and India.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "How BRAC, the world’s biggest charity, made Bangladesh richer", published in the International section of The Economist's print edition on September 5, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: How BRAC, the world’s biggest charity, made Bangladesh richer

definition: Many and of various types
passage: The forces responsible for stagnant and sinking working-class wages—globalisation, automation... not to mention the multifarious causes underlying anaemic rates of economic growth—are barely within the ken of experts.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Blame Mexico!", published in The Economist's American politics blog on August 18, 2015. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Blame Mexico!

definition: The capacity to recover quickly from difficulties
passage: The resilience of Joseph Muscat’s Labour government has been a wonder to behold. For six years, fortified by the support that comes with rapid economic growth... it has withstood sleaze allegations that would have toppled other administrations.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The murder of a journalist in 2017 still haunts Malta’s government", published in the Europe section of The Economist's print edition on November 28, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The murder of a journalist in 2017 still haunts Malta’s government

definition: Having a smoothly rising and falling form or outline
passage: For an illustration, drive north from Warsaw into Mazowsze. The region is as gorgeous as a Chopin concerto, an undulating quilt of cereal fields and birch groves, but in the 1990s its towns were unromantically down-at-heel.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Poland’s ruling Law and Justice party is doing lasting damage", published in the Europe section of The Economist's print edition on April 21, 2018. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Poland’s ruling Law and Justice party is doing lasting damage

definition: Obtain (something) by devious or dishonest means
passage: In a classic DC scheme, the cost to the employers is clear but the benefit to the worker is not... A collective DC scheme tries to finagle this problem by giving workers a claim, but a claim that can be reduced if the assets fall short of target.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Not Ponzis, but pyramids", published in The Economist's "Buttonwood's notebook" blog on June 16, 2014. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Not Ponzis, but pyramids

definition: A person or thing that is a perfect example of a particular quality or type
passage: Asked if she is tough enough to take on President Donald Trump as president, Amy Klobuchar—a senator long known as the epitome of Minnesotan nice—refers to the heavens.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Amy Klobuchar declares", published in The Economist's American politics blog on February 11, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Amy Klobuchar declares

definition: An embankment built to prevent the overflow of a river
passage: In many instances humans have betrayed their biases and performed the 'mental time-travel' necessary to plan ahead: when they establish earthquake-proof building codes, build flood levees, forge nuclear non-proliferation agreements and the like.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "We’re designed to make bad choices but here’s what we can do", published in The Economist's "Open Future" blog on December 6, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: We’re designed to make bad choices but here’s what we can do

definition: Cause to become twisted together with or caught in
passage: We suggest five strategies to narrow the empathic divide... Fifth, entangle group memberships. Work to ensure that communities are intertwined.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Does your brain care about other people? It depends", published in the Leaders section of The Economist's print edition on November 4, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Does your brain care about other people? It depends

definition: Steal or misappropriate (money placed in one's trust or belonging to the organization for which one works)
passage: Impeachment, wrote James Madison, would be appropriate if a president lost his capacity to do the job after being elected, if a president were to take bribes or embezzle money...
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Robert Mueller has submitted his report. What now?", published in the Briefing section of The Economist on March 23, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Robert Mueller has submitted his report. What now?

definition: Join; combine
passage: Taiwan’s president, Ma Ying-jeou, elected in 2008, has conjoined Taiwan’s economy ever closer with China’s.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Told you so", published in the Asia section of The Economist's print edition on November 1, 2014. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Told you so

definition: (in an auction or when seeking a contract) make a lower bid than (someone)
synonyms: charge a lower price than, undersell
passage: In any given contemporary auction week, a fair number of the Warhols will have been either consigned, underbid or bought by the Mugrabi family, sometimes in partnership with Larry Gagosian...
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The wizards of the Warhol market", published in The Economist's Books, art and culture blog on May 17, 2011. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The wizards of the Warhol market

definition: A speech or text publicly criticizing (someone or something) by using ridicule, irony, or sarcasm
passage: Whether that’s true or not, Mexico’s high-and-mighty generally enjoy undeserved immunity from lampoon; this film makes a boisterous attempt to redress the balance.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Laughing at power", published in The Economist's Books, art and culture blog on October 22, 2014. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Laughing at power

definition: The process of burning something
passage: The changing climate of the planet and the remarkable growth in human numbers and riches both stem from the combustion of billions of tonnes of fossil fuel to produce industrial power, electricity, transport, heating and, more recently, computation.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The climate issue", published in the Leaders section of The Economist's print edition on September 19, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The climate issue

definition: Having a pleasant or sweet smell
passage: Here, an array of loose-leaf samples, from smoky Lapsang Souchong to perfumed jasmine and fragrant Darjeeling, tantalise the nostrils.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The ambivalent history of the Camellia sinensis leaf", published in The Economist's Books, art and culture blog on July 10, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The ambivalent history of the Camellia sinensis leaf

definition: A large fire that is dangerously out of control
passage: It is in the nature of horrific tragedies that they bring communities together. Firemen and paramedics risked their lives to tame the raging inferno and save whoever they could.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The politics of a tragedy", published in The Economist's "Bagehot's notebook" blog on June 16, 2017. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The politics of a tragedy

definition: (of a place) extremely dirty and unpleasant, especially as a result of poverty or neglect
passage: The devastation of their country currently makes return very uninviting, particularly for refugees in Europe, who live in relative comfort compared with their compatriots in squalid camps in Lebanon or Jordan.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Syria’s war is drawing to a close. But the pain will go on", published in the Briefing section of The Economist's print edition on September 5, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Syria’s war is drawing to a close. But the pain will go on

definition: Solicit votes from (electors in a constituency)
passage: On March 6th GeenPeil’s campaign rolled into Heerhugowaard, a town of red-brick modern developments... Some of the entourage went to canvass voters while Mr Nijman stayed on the bus, typing ceaselessly on a laptop.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Dutch voters’ anger is fuelling populism", published in the Europe section of The Economist's print edition on March 9, 2017. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Dutch voters’ anger is fuelling populism

definition: Saturated with liquid, especially water; soaked through
passage: Wimbledon’s two retractable-roofed courts allow big matches to continue in a downpour. The switch from outside to indoors affects more than just sodden spectators, however.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Typhoon Hagibis offers a glimpse of sport’s stormy future", published in The Economist's "Game theory" blog on October 14, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Typhoon Hagibis offers a glimpse of sport’s stormy future

definition: Lasting for a long time or longer than expected or usual
passage: But precautions can look like provocations. In allowing the yuan to fall, China signalled it is prepared for a protracted trade war.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The trade war escalates, and the fog of war descends", published in the Finance and economics section of The Economist's print edition on August 8, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The trade war escalates, and the fog of war descends

definition: An invasion or attack, especially a sudden or brief one
synonyms: attack on, assault on, raid on
passage: As Turkey advances, the fighting will probably grow bloodier....The incursion could displace many of the 750,000 people living along the border.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Turkey launches an attack on northern Syria", published in the Middle East and Africa section of The Economist's print edition on October 10, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Turkey launches an attack on northern Syria

definition: The intervening time
passage: He served around 60 people every month until the venue closed, but will soon open a new place... in the south of the city. In the interim, he has been working at a market stall to learn more about the food trade.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Refugees make great entrepreneurs and workers", published in the Business section of The Economist's print edition on November 21, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Refugees make great entrepreneurs and workers

definition: (of a disease) causing no symptoms but not cured and liable to recur
passage: What does it take to neuter and dissipate a conspiracy narrative? Can that even be done, or will they always live on like a dormant virus?
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Conspiracy theories are dangerous—here’s how to crush them", published in The Economist's "Open Future" blog on August 12, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Conspiracy theories are dangerous—here’s how to crush them

definition: Very old or old-fashioned
passage: You foresee new international institutions to replace archaic 20th-century ones that are suited for a different time. How would they work?
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Globalisation is dead and we need to invent a new world order", published in The Economist's "Open Future" blog on June 28, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Globalisation is dead and we need to invent a new world order

definition: Lose or give up (something) as a necessary consequence of something else
passage: One recent study found that the typical user would need to be paid $17,530 to agree to forfeit access to a search engine for a year, compared with $322 for social-media sites, such as Facebook.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Who will control Alphabet once Sergey Brin and Larry Page are gone?", published in the Leaders section of The Economist's print edition on December 7, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Who will control Alphabet once Sergey Brin and Larry Page are gone?

definition: Not to be relied upon; suspect
passage: The fact that dubious claims are made about inequality does not reduce the urgency of tackling economic injustice. But it does call for ensuring that the assumptions on which policies are based are accurate.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Inequality could be lower than you think", published in the Leaders section of The Economist's print edition on November 28, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Inequality could be lower than you think

definition: Relating to trees
passage: An entire discipline, known as dendrochronology, is devoted to using tree rings to date ancient wooden objects and buildings. Linguistic archaeologists, it seems, share these arboreal inclinations, though the trees they examine are of an altogether different species.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The tree of knowledge", published in The Economist's "Johnson" blog on August 25, 2012. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The tree of knowledge

definition: Proud haughtiness of manner
passage: Yet along the way, Mr Macron forgot that a French president is neither a god nor a monarch but merely a politician in a democracy... His hauteur has led to a series of individually small but cumulatively destructive missteps...
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Emmanuel Macron’s problems are more with presentation than policy", published in the Leaders section of The Economist's print edition on December 8, 2018. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Emmanuel Macron’s problems are more with presentation than policy

definition: A passionate expression of grief or sorrow
passage: If you watch much too much televised football... you will often hear a particular lament. Whatever happened to the playmakers, the socks-rolled-down mavericks whose individualism could alter the course of a match?
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Do not write off the macro hedge-fund manager just yet", published in the Finance and economics section of The Economist's print edition on November 28, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Do not write off the macro hedge-fund manager just yet

definition: Arranged or existing for the present, possibly to be changed later
passage: Yet for all this activity, there is a provisional quality to the rising edifice of European defence. Europeans see the storms coming and know they must build.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Europe needs to defend itself better, but cannot do without America", published in the Europe section of The Economist's print edition on November 21, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Europe needs to defend itself better, but cannot do without America

definition: Possessing or showing courage or determination
passage: His primary audience in Strasbourg was not MEPs but domestic voters, and the defeat will only serve to boost his popularity, as he presents himself as a valiant defender of the beleaguered Hungarian nation against the hostile external forces (that pay its bills).
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The European Parliament condemns Hungary", published in the Europe section of The Economist's print edition on September 13, 2018. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The European Parliament condemns Hungary

definition: The state of being very poor; extreme poverty
passage: Middle-class families, too, are slipping into penury as they exhaust their savings. Poverty has soared.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Rises in the price of petrol are fuelling unrest in Iran", published in the Middle East and Africa section of The Economist's print edition on November 21, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Rises in the price of petrol are fuelling unrest in Iran

definition: Assertive of authority in a domineering way, especially with regard to trivial matters
passage: Mark Bittman, the New York Times' resident food guru, wants the government more heavily involved in engineering Americans' diets... I'm not going to pretend this sort of officious paternalism doesn't annoy the hell out of me, but... if we're going to do this, we ought to do it right.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Tax the fat, not their food", published in The Economist's American politics blog on July 26, 2011. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Tax the fat, not their food

definition: Unable to be appeased or placated
passage: Western donors have privately shared their misgivings with the president. Mr Condé, though, seems unfazed, perhaps because he has the backing of an implacable opponent of the West: Russia.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "The Kremlin is encouraging Guinea’s president to ditch the constitution", published in the Middle East and Africa section of The Economist's print edition on October 21, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: The Kremlin is encouraging Guinea’s president to ditch the constitution

definition: An earnest or humble request
passage: Take her entreaty to Germans during the refugee crisis: 'Wir schaffen das' (meaning 'We’ll manage it' or 'We can do it'). Who precisely was the 'we' there?
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "How Angela Merkel speaks", published in The Economist's "Kaffeeklatsch" blog on September 3, 2017. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: How Angela Merkel speaks

definition: Speak or write about (something) with great hostility
passage: In 2015 Mr Netanyahu accepted congressional Republicans’ invitation to address a joint session of Congress, where he inveighed against the nuclear deal that Mr Obama brokered with Iran.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Donald Trump presses Israel into barring entry to American congresswomen", published in The Economist's American politics blog on August 16, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Donald Trump presses Israel into barring entry to American congresswomen

definition: Agree to give up or do without
passage: The North gave two reasons for its ire: long-scheduled military exercises... and America’s insistence that it must unilaterally forswear nuclear arms—the very condition on which America agreed to talks in the first place.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "North Korea reminds the world why past peace talks have failed", published in the Asia section of The Economist's print edition on May 17, 2018. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: North Korea reminds the world why past peace talks have failed

definition: Destroy completely; put an end to
passage: Polio will remain in only Afghanistan and Pakistan; and one day it will be completely eradicated, like smallpox was in 1980.
caption: Today's #GRE #wordoftheday comes from "Africa is on the verge of being declared polio-free", published in the Middle East and Africa section of The Economist's print edition on August 22, 2019. Stay tuned for more vocabulary to aid in your #GREPrep
sourceTitle: Africa is on the verge of being declared polio-free

definition: Receptive or aware
